oldRegime: Multiple slabs with progressive rates starting from 5% to 30%
newRegime: Simplified slabs with rates starting from 5% to 30% but with lower thresholds

oldRegime: Allows deductions like 80C (₹1.5 lakh), 80D (health insurance), HRA, etc.
newRegime: No major deductions allowed except employer's NPS contribution (Section 80CCD(2))

oldRegime: Includes exemptions like Leave Travel Allowance (LTA), House Rent Allowance (HRA), and Standard Deduction
newRegime: Limited exemptions; Standard Deduction of ₹50,000 is allowed for salaried individuals (from FY 2023-24)

oldRegime: Rebate of up to ₹12,500 for individuals with income up to ₹5 lakh
newRegime: Rebate of up to ₹25,000 for individuals with income up to ₹7 lakh (from FY 2023-24)

oldRegime: More beneficial for those with significant investments and expenses eligible for deductions
newRegime: Beneficial for those with minimal investments and simpler tax filing needs

oldRegime: Requires maintaining detailed documentation for claiming deductions and exemptions
newRegime: Simpler tax filing process with fewer documents needed

oldRegime: Standard deduction of ₹50,000 for salaried individuals
newRegime: Standard deduction of ₹50,000 included for salaried individuals (from FY 2023-24)

oldRegime: Best for individuals who can claim significant deductions and exemptions
newRegime: Best for individuals who prefer lower tax rates without deductions

oldRegime: Optional, taxpayers need to choose this regime explicitly while filing returns
newRegime: Default option, taxpayers can opt for the old regime if beneficial
